# R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents [@deCarvalho2012]. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

```{r}
# === Langkah 1: Load Data ===
# Pastikan file HeatingOil.csv ada di direktori kerja Anda
data <- read.csv("HeatingOil.csv")

# Tampilkan beberapa baris pertama
head(data)

# === Langkah 2: Correlation Matrix & Heatmap ===
# Install package jika belum terpasang
# install.packages("corrplot")
# install.packages("ggplot2")
# install.packages("RColorBrewer")

library(corrplot)
library(RColorBrewer)

# Hitung matriks korelasi
cor_matrix <- cor(data)

# Tampilkan heatmap korelasi
corrplot(cor_matrix, method = "color", col = brewer.pal(8, "RdBu"),
         type = "upper", addCoef.col = "black", tl.col = "black",
         tl.cex = 0.8, number.cex = 0.7, title = "Correlation Matrix")

# === Langkah 3: Scatter Plot - Heating_Oil vs Avg_Age ===
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x = Heating_Oil, y = Avg_Age, color = Heating_Oil)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "yellow") +
  labs(title = "Heating_Oil vs Avg_Age",
       x = "Heating_Oil",
       y = "Average Age") +
  theme_minimal()

# === Langkah 4: Scatter Plot - Temperature vs Insulation (warna: Heating_Oil) ===
ggplot(data, aes(x = Temperature, y = Insulation, color = Heating_Oil)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "red") +
  labs(title = "Temperature vs Insulation (Colored by Heating_Oil)",
       x = "Temperature",
       y = "Insulation") +
  theme_minimal()

```


Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
